author: Justin Huggler
title: Germany to boost army to 200,000 troops amid growing concern over Donald Trump's commitment to Nato
text:
G ermany is to increase the size of its armed forces amid growing concerns over the security of Europe.
Troop numbers in the Bundeswehr will be raised to almost 200,000 over the next seven years, under new plans announced on Wednesday.
The move comes days after Mike Pence, the US vice-president, called on Nato’s European members to increase military spending. 
The Bundeswehr has rarely been as necessary as it is now German defence minister Ursula von der Leyen P resident Donald Trump has repeatedly demanded Europe pay more towards the cost of its own defence.
The move also comes amid growing concern in European capitals over Mr Trumps’ commitment to Nato , after he described the alliance as “obsolete”.
Under the new plans, Germany will recruit 20,000 more troops by 2025, bringing its total service personnel to 198,000.
That is slightly more than the British armed forces’ current strength of 196,410.
Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg shakes hands with visiting US vice president Mike Pence at a press conference after their meeting at Nato headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, on February 20 Credit: Xinhua / Barcroft Images I n a statement announcing the plans, Ursula von der Leyen, the defence minister, said: “The Bundeswehr has rarely been as necessary as it is now.
“Whether it is the fight against Isil terrorism, the stabilization of Mali, continuing support of Afghanistan, operations against migrant smugglers in the Mediterranean or with our increased Nato presence in the Baltics.”
German Bundeswehr Soldiers of the 'battalion of armored infantryman' called 'Panzergrenadierbataillon 122' sit on a wrecker called 'Bueffel' during vehicles wait to be loaded onto a train in Grafenwoehr, Germany, 31 January 2017, before being deployed as part of a NATO force in Lithuania Credit: LUKAS BARTH/EPA T he announcement came as Germany deployed tanks and hundreds troops to Lithuania as part of a Nato force to deter Russian aggression.
During the Cold War, West Germany was considered the first line of defence against a Soviet invasion and at its height the Bundesweher had 500,000 active service personnel.
